What you know or what you suspects of the young galoot that 's married the gal ain't worth shucks to anybody, and I wouldn't give it to a yaller pup to play with, but the Judge thinks you ought all to promise right here that you '11 keep it dark. That 's his opin ion. Ez far as my opinion goes, gen'l'men, I wanter simply re mark, in a keerless, offhand gin'ral way, that ef I ketch any God-forsaken, lop eared, chuckle-headed blatherin' idjet airin' Ms opinion
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: One moment, Bill, let me explain. You understand, gentlemen, the singular, and I may say affecting, situation which our good hearted friend here has done so much to bring to what we hope will be a happy ter mination. I want to give here, as my pro fessional opinion, that there is nothing in his request which, in your capacity as good citizens and law-abiding men, you may not grant. I want to tell you, also, that you are condoning no offense against the stat utes; that there is not a particle of legal evidence before us of the criminal antece dents of Mr. Charles Byng, except that which has been told you by the innocent lips of his betrothed, which the law of the land has now sealed forever in the mouth of his wife, and that our own actual experi ence of his acts have been in the main ex culpatory of any previous irregularity if not incompatible with it. Briefly, no judge would charge, no jury convict, on such evi dence. When I add that the young girl is of legal age, that there is no evidence of any previous undue influence, but rather of the reverse, on the part of the bridegroom, and that I was content, as a magistrate, to perform the ceremony, I think you will be satisfied to give your promise, for the sake of the bride, and drink a happy life to them both.
speaker: Judge Thompson

utterance: You see, when your old Uncle Bill takes hold of a job like this, he puts it straight through without changin' hosses. Yet thar was a moment, young feller, when I thought I was stompt ! It was when we 'd made up our mind to make that chap tell the gal fust all what he was! Ef she 'd rared or kicked in the traces, or hung back only ez much ez that, we 'd hev given him jest five minits' law to get up and get and leave her, and we 'd hev toted that gal and her fixin's back to her dad again! But she jest gave a little scream and start, and then went off inter hysterics, right on his buz zum, laughing and cry in' and say in' that nothin' should part 'em. Gosh! if I didn't think he woz more cut up than she about it ; a minit it looked as ef he didn't allow to marry her arter all, but that passed, and they was married hard and fast you bet ! I reckon he 's had enough of stay in' out o' nights to last him, and ef the valley settle ments hev n't got hold of a very shining member, at least the foothills hev got shut of one more of the Ramon Martinez gang.' 5

utterance: And you won't for the fact is, the gang is about played out. Not from want of a job now and then, but from the difficulty of disposing of the re sults of their work. Since the new instruc tions to the agents to identify and trace all dust and bullion offered to them went into force, you see, they can't get rid of their swag. All the gang are spotted at the offices, and it costs too much for them to pay a fence or a middleman of any stand ing. Why, all that flaky river gold they took from the Excelsior Company can be identified as easy as if it was stamped with the company's mark. They can't melt it down themselves; they can't get others to do it for them; they can't ship it to the Mint or Assay Offices in Marysville and 'Frisco, for they won't take it without our certificate and seals ; and we don't take any undeclared freight within the lines that we 've drawn around their beat, except from people and agents known. utterance: It 's done.

Thar 's plenty of wood and water up thar, and the company 's sure to have a wharf down on the shore. I '11 provide the capital, if you will put in your time. You can sling in ez much style as you like there in fact, the more style the better for them city folks. Well, you think it over.
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

Perhaps you think so because you looked down on us when you first came here.

utterance: But I didn't.

Humph! You '11 have to be rather  careful about these solitary married women.
 We don't want another scandal, you know.
speaker: James Reddy

utterance: Jim,
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

When I got  my divorce from Dick you didn't know that either, I suppose; it's three months  ago, I did n't care to take my maiden  name again; too many people remembered  it. So after the decree was made I called  myself Mrs. Merrydew. You had disap peared. They said you had gone East.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: But the clerk says you are expecting  your husband on the steamer. What does  this mean? Why did you tell him that?
speaker: James Reddy

utterance: You see, Jim, as soon as I was free,  Louis Sylvester you remember Louis  Sylvester? wanted to marry me, and even  thought that he was the cause of- Dick's  divorcing me. He actually went East to  settle up some property he had left him  there, and he 's coming on the steamer.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: Louis Sylvester! Why, he was a bigger  fool than I was, and a worse man !
speaker: James Reddy

utterance:
I believe he was, and I think he still is. But, you you're regularly re formed, aren't you? You're stouter, too,  and altogether more solid and commercial  looking. Yet who 'd have thought of your  keeping a hotel or ever doing anything but  speculate in wild-cat or play at draw poker.
 How did you drift into it ? Come, tell me !
 I 'm not Mrs. Sylvester just yet, and maybe  I might like to go into the business too.
 You don't want a partner, do you?
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: The same old Jim, and yet I thought you had forgotten all  that now, and become calmer and more sen sible since you had taken flesh and grown  so matter of fact. You ought to have  known then, as you know now, that I never  could have been anything to you as long  as I was tied to Dick. And you know you  forced your presents on me, Jim. I took  them from you because I would take no thing from Dick, for I hated him. And  I never knew positively that you were in  straits then; you know you always talked  big, Jim, and were always going to make  your fortune with the next thing you had in  hand!
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: Then you had presents from Sylvester,  too. I presume you did not hate him,  either?
speaker: James Reddy

utterance: He would have married me the day  after I got my divorce.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: And so would I,
speaker: James Reddy

utterance: You would ?
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: And  now
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: No  matter now. Let us talk of something  nearer. That was two months ago. And  so you have charge of this hotel ! I like it  so much. I mean the place itself. I fancy  I could live here forever. It is so far away  and restful. I am so sick of towns and  cities, and people. And this little grove  is so secluded. If one had merely a little  cottage here, one might be so happy.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: But you  can't stay here. The rules are very strin gent in regard to to strangers like your self. It will be known who you really are  and what people say of you. Even your  divorce will tell against you. It 's all  wrong, I know but what can I do? I  didn't make the rules. I am only a ser vant of the landlord, and must carry them  out.
speaker: James Reddy

utterance:
Don't be alarmed, my  poor Jim! If you mean your friend, Mr.
 Woodridge, I know him. It was he, him self, who suggested my coming here. And  don't misunderstand him nor me either.
 He's only a good friend of Sylvester's;  they had some speculation together. He 's  coming here to see me after Louis arrives.
 He 's waiting in San Francisco for his wife  and daughter, who come on the same  steamer. So you see you won't get into  trouble on my account. Don't look so  scared, my dear boy.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: Does he know that you knew me?
speaker: James Reddy

utterance: Perhaps. But then that was three  months ago, and you know how you have reformed  since, and grown ever so much more steady  and respectable.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: Did he talk to you of me?
speaker: James Reddy

utterance:
A little complimentary of course.
 Don't look so frightened. I didn't give  you away.
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: There 's Mr. Woodridge now, The  steamer must be in. But I don't see Louis;  do you?
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance:
I would n't have disturbed you, Mrs.
 Merry dew, if I hadn't wanted to ask your  advice before I saw Keddy. I 'm keeping  out of his way until I could see you. I left  Nelly and her mother in 'Frisco. There 's  been some queer goings-on 011 the steamer  coming home; Nelly has sprung a new  game on her mother, and and suthin'
 that looks as if there might be a new deal.
 However,
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: that is as may be.
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance:
I don't know, as I ever  told you anything about my Nelly and  Reddy, partik'lerly about Nelly. She 's  a good girl, a square girl, but she 's got  some all-fired romantic ideas in her head.
 Mebbee it kem from her reading, mebbee  it kem from her not knowing other girls,  or seeing too much of a queer sort of men ;  but she got an interest in the bad ones, and  thought it was her mission to reform them,  reform them by pure kindness, attentive  little sisterly ways, and moral example.
 She first tried her hand on Eeddy. When  he first kem to us he was well, he was  a blazin' ruin ! She took him in hand,  yanked him outer himself, put his foot on  the bedrock, and made him what you see  him now. Well what happened $ why,  he got reg'larly soft on her; wanted to  marry her, and I agreed conditionally, of  course, to keep him up to the mark. Did  you speak?
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: No,
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance:
Well, that was all well and good, and  I 'd liked to have carried out my part of  the contract, and was willing, and am still.
 But you see, Nelly, after she 'd landed  Reddy on firm ground, got a little tired, I  reckon, gal-like, of the thing she 'd worked  so easily, and when she went East she  looked around for some other wreck to try  her hand on, and she found it on the  steamer coming back. And who do you  think it was? Why, our friend Louis  Sylvester!
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: Well, you know he is fast at times if  he is a friend of mine and she reg'larly  tackled him ; and as my old woman says, it  was a sight to see her go for him. But  then he didn't tumble to it. No! Re formin' ain't in his line I 'm afeard. And  what was the result? Why, Nelly only got  all the more keen when she found she  couldn't manage him like Reddy, and,  between you and me, she 'd have liked  Reddy more if he had n't been so easy,  and it 's ended, I reckon, in her now falling  dead in love with Sylvester. She swears  she won't marry any one else, and wants to  devote her whole life to him! Now, what 's  to be done! Keddy don't know it yet, and  I don't know how to tell him. Nelly says  her mission was ended when she made a  new man of him, and he oughter be thank ful for that. Couldn't you kinder break  the news to him and tell him there ain't  any show for him?
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: Does he love the girl so much, then?
speaker: Mrs. Merrydew

utterance: Yes; but I am afraid there is no hope  for Reddy as long as she thinks there 's a  chance of her capturing Sylvester.
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: Would it be any comfort to you,  Mr. Woodridge, if you were told that she  had not the slightest chance with Sylves ter?

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Mr. Woodridge

utterance: Find out where Sylvester is in San Fran cisco, and give him that card. I think it  will satisfy you. And now as I have to  catch the return coach in ten minutes, I  must ask you to excuse me while I put my  things together.

thar 's a bit of America.
 Sit down thar. You 're under the flag now,  and can do as you darn please.

 else. ' But I reckon you float it over your  house, eh?

speaker: Harry Ouster

Yes, I oughter say  the only McHulish. He is the direct heir  and of royal descent ! He 's one of them  McHulishes whose name in them old history  times was enough to whoop up the boys and  make 'em paint the town red. A regular  campaign boomer the old McHulish was.
 Stump speeches and brass-bands warn't in  it with the boys when he was around.
 They 'd go their bottom dollar and last car tridge if they 'd had cartridges in them  days on him. That was the regular Mc Hulish gait. And Malcolm there 's the  last of 'em got the same style of features,  too.
speaker: Harry Ouster

utterance: Of course our young friend has no de sire to test the magic of his name here, in  these degenerate days.
speaker: the consul

speaker: Harry Ouster

utterance: Whatever possessed folks to build  there? If they were  poor, it might be some excuse; but that  those old swells, or chiefs, should put up a  castle in such a God-forsaken place gets  me.

utterance: I fancy, don't you know, that it wasn't exactly  that sort of thing, you know, for it 's a  good way from the border; but it was one  of their raids upon their neighbors, to lift  their cattle steal 'em, in fact. utterance: Eh, but they were often reprisals,^

utterance: I don't suppose they took much trouble  to inquire if the beasts belonged to an en emy,

Really, you know, they oughtn't to have  induced you to take tickets there those  excursion - ticket chaps. They 're jolly  frauds. It 's no place for a stranger to  goto.

utterance: But there are the ruins of an old castle,  the old seat of

speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Whose is it?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: It wasn't there in my time,
speaker: young man

utterance: But it is there in our time, and / propose to go there. From what you have told me of your father even if his house were still standing our chances of getting supper and a bed from him would be doubtful ! I suppose, you left him in anger five years ago?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Ye-es.
speaker: young man

utterance: Did he say anything as you left?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: I don't remember anything particular that he said.
speaker: young man

utterance: Well, what did he do ?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Shot at me from the window!
speaker: young man

utterance: Ah!
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: I did n't, say anything about your father. You can make inquiries yourself later.
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: I reckon there won't be much need of that. You didn't take much note o' that man, did you?
speaker: young man

utterance: Not much,
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Well, that's my father, and I reckon that new house must be his.
speaker: young man

utterance: Look here, he 's not there now. Why don't you seize the opportunity to slip into the house, make peace with your mother and sisters, and get them to intercede with your father when he returns?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Thar ain't any mother; she died afore I left. My sister Almiry 's a little girl though that 's four years ago and mebbee she 's growed. My brothers and me didn't pull together much. But I was thinkin' that mebbee you might go in thar for me first, and see how the land lays ; then sorter tell 'em 'bout me in your takin', chipper, easy way; make 'em laugh, and when you 've squared 'em I '11 be hangin' round outside you kin call me in. Don't you see?
speaker: Jim

utterance: But you must tell me something more of yourself, and your fortune and pros pects. They '11 be sure to ask questions.
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Mebbee they won't. But you can say I 've done well made my pile over in Australia, and ain't comin' on them. Re member say I ' ain't comin' on them ' !
speaker: Jim

utterance: This gentleman, Mr. Grey, of the ' Argus, ' has come across Jim and Jim is calculating to come here and see father.
speaker: Almira

utterance: One moment, I have no desire to penetrate family se crets, but would you mind telling me if there is any grave reason why he should not come. Was there any scandalous conduct, unpardonable offense let us even say any criminal act on his part which makes his return to this roof impossible?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: No, no,
speaker: Almira and her brothers

utterance: No, only
speaker: Almira and her brothers

utterance: Only what?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Dad just hates him!
speaker: Almira and her brothers

utterance: Like pizon,
speaker: Almira

utterance: Look here,
speaker: Almira

utterance: Dad 's gone down to the sheep fold and won't be back for an hour. Yo' might bring yo* friend in.
speaker: Almira

utterance: He ain't wantin' anything? Ain't dead broke? nor nothin', eh?
speaker: one of the brothers

utterance: Go and fetch him, and mind yo 1 come back, too!
speaker: Almira

utterance: Your sister and brothers will see you,
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: He won't be here for an hour. But I 'd advise you to make the most of your time, and get the good -will of your sister.
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: The old house got burnt!
speaker: Jim

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the elder brother

utterance: Almira 's growed.
speaker: Jim

utterance: You've done well?
speaker: one of the brothers

utterance: Yes, I 'm all right,
speaker: Jim

utterance: I see the old well is there yet,
speaker: Jim

utterance: Where dad was once goin' to chuck you down for givin' him back talk,
speaker: the younger brother

utterance: That's so how old times do come back!
speaker: Jim

utterance: And, there 's that old butternut-tree that you shinned up one day when we set the hounds on you. Goodness! how you scooted!
speaker: Almira

utterance: Yes, the same old butternut. How you do remember, Almira!
speaker: Jim

utterance: And don't you remember Delia Short? She, you know, you was reg'larly sick after, so that we always allowed she kinder turned yo' brain afore you went away! Well! all the while you were courtin' her it appears she was secretly married to Jo - yo' friend Jo Stacy. Lord! there was a talk about that ! and about yo' all along thinkin' yo' had chances! Yo' friend here, who 's allus puttin' folks in the newspapers, orter get a hold on that!
speaker: Almira

utterance: You say your father will return in an hour?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Yes, unless he kept 011 to Watson's.
speaker: the elder brother

utterance: Where?
speaker: Jim

utterance: Watson's, just over the bridge, If he went there he won't be back till ten.
speaker: the elder brother

utterance: I reckon I '11 just take a turn outside until he gets back,
speaker: Jim

utterance: I '11 go with you,
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: No, You stay here and keep 'em up cheerful like this. They 're doing all this for you, you know; Almiry 's just this chipper only on your account.
speaker: Jim

utterance: Why, dad! what 's up ? Yo' look half drowned !
speaker: the two brothers

utterance: Half drowned. Yes! and I might have been hull drowned for that matter. The back water of the Fork is all over Wat son's, and the bridge is gone. I stumbled onto this end of it in the dark, and went off, head first, into twenty feet of water! Tried to fight my way out, but the current was agin me. I 'd bin down twice, and was going down for the third time, when somebody grabbed me by the scruff o' my neck and under the arm so ! and swam me to the bank ! When I scrambled up I sez: C I can't see your face,' sez I, 'I don't know who you are,' sez I, 'but I reckon you 're a white man and clear grit, ' sez I, ' and there 's my hand on it ! ' And he grabs it and sez, 'We 're quits,' and scooted out o' my sight. And, who do you think it was? Why, that sneakin' hound of a brother of yours Jim ! Jim ! the scalla wag that I booted outer the ranch five years ago, crawlin', writhin' back again after all these years to insult his old father's gray hairs ! And some of you by God once thought that / was hard on him 1
speaker: Wilkes

utterance: We had a gay talk last night, remem bering old times, did n't we ?
speaker: Jim

utterance: Yes, but where are you going now?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Back to Australia, I reckon! But it was mighty good to drop in on the old homestead once more !
speaker: Jim

utterance: but I say look here ! were you quite satis fied?
speaker: Mr.Grey

utterance: Yes.
